docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre, an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, writes about the economics of public support for family planning.
docs.abstract: Increased public spending on family planning would generate about as many direct and indirect jobs as any other health expenditures, and probably more than an equivalent tax cut. But the short-term effects are less important than benefits down the road, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Increased public spending on family planning would generate about as many direct and indirect jobs as any other health expenditures, and probably more than an equivalent tax cut. But the short-term effects are less important than benefits down the...

docs.lead_paragraph: MVP Health Care agreed on Wednesday to pay $535,000 to resolve a state inquiry into how it reimburses clients for services from out-of-network physicians.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House gave final approval to a bill extending health insurance to millions of low-income children, and President Obama signed it.

headline.main: Obama Signs Children’s Health Insurance Bill

docs.snippet: The House gave final approval to a bill extending health insurance to millions of low-income children, and President Obama signed it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite popular misconceptions, Medicaid doesn’t insure everyone who is poor; proposed legislation to cover healthy workers who have been laid off is “unprecedented,” experts say.

headline.main: Don’t We Already Have a Health Plan for the Poor?
headline.print_headline: Don’t We Already Have a Health Plan for the Poor?

docs.snippet: Despite popular misconceptions, Medicaid doesn’t insure everyone who is poor; proposed legislation to cover healthy workers who have been laid off is “unprecedented,” experts say.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a White House ceremony, President Obama signed legislation on Wednesday that extends health coverage to four million uninsured children, a move he called a first step toward fulfilling a campaign pledge to provide insurance for all Americans.

headline.main: Expansion of Health Insurance for Children Becomes Law

docs.snippet: In a White House ceremony, President Obama signed legislation on Wednesday that extends health coverage to four million uninsured children, a move he called a first step toward fulfilling a campaign pledge to provide insurance for all Americans.
